qas.question: Along with mood, temperament, disposition and motivation, what is emotion often tied to?
What do some theories see as an important part of emotion?
Along with sweating and muscle tension, what might be a physiological response to danger?
Sweating is a product of the arousal of what system?
Along with mood, temperament, disposition and motivation, what is emotion never tied to?
What do some theories see as an unimportant part of emotion?

plausible_answers.text: rapid heartbeat and breathing, sweating, muscle tension

qas.question: Along with sweating and muscle tension, what might be a non-physiological response to danger?
Sweating is a not product of the arousal of what system?

context: Emotion, in everyday speech, is any relatively brief conscious experience characterized by intense mental activity and a high degree of pleasure or displeasure. Scientific discourse has drifted to other meanings and there is no consensus on a definition. Emotion is often intertwined with mood, temperament, <a0_0><b4_0>personality<b4_0/><a0_0/>, disposition, and motivation. In some theories, <a1_0>cognition<a1_0/> is an important aspect of emotion. Those acting primarily on emotion may seem as if they are not thinking, but mental processes are still essential, particularly in the interpretation of events. For example, the realization of danger and subsequent arousal of the <a3_0><b7_0>nervous<a3_0/> system<b7_0/> (e.g. <a2_0><b6_0>rapid heartbeat and breathing<a2_0/>, sweating, muscle tension<b6_0/>) is integral to the experience of fear. Other theories, however, claim that emotion is separate from and can precede <b5_0>cognition<b5_0/>.
